abstract.text: Detailed description of currently supported methods and data models which are used to communicate with your server.

inlineContent.text: A client object can be initialized in two different ways - and requires to provide login data. Either by username/password or access tokens retrieved by a previous session. The following initializers are implemented as failable and will do so, if their parameters are provided with an empty string.
: server url, authentication by username and password
: server url, authentication by access token retrieved from a previous session
A thrid option with a custom http session handler exists
but is intentionally not marked as public because its main purpose is to be used with a mock http client for unit testing.
The following listing shows initialization by username and password. After initialization, make sure to register a specific error handler for your application.
is always called when a request to the server fails. The cause of failure doesn’t matter (e.g. server not reachable, incorrect authentication or incorrect server request).

code: let myClient = try? TBUserApiClient(baseUrlStr: "https://my-thingsboard-iot-server.com", username: "MyUsername", password: "MySuperSecretPassword")

inlineContent.text: Types involved:
When client is initialized with username/password
method can be called afterwards. This generates a login token which remains with the client until it is deinitalized or cleand up.
Types involved:

Initialization can also be performed by using a previosuly feteched access token (instead of username/password). The procedure mainly stays the same as described above: init client, then register error handler

code: let myClient2 = try? TBUserApiClient(baseUrlStr: "https://my-thingsboard-iot-server.com", accessToken: accessToken)

content.text: Login when initialized with access token

inlineContent.text: When initialized with an access token it may be the case to
renew
the login (e.g. because the server rejects an invalidated access token). In this case
needs to be called to obtain a new access token.
Types involved:

To perform user-specific requests (e.g. user-accessible devices or profiles) it is mandatorry to include a user-id reference to these requests. Therefore it is required to obtain its own user-id first. More details about
Types involved:
Working with devices and device profiles.

Get devices and device infos for the customer the user belongs to. Response supports pagination. This is automatically neglected when using default arguments for function parameters, assuming a response with decent number of devices.
gives more flexibility compared to
. To minimize complexity, return type is the same for both functions.

code: // picking up all devices assuming there are not hundreds/thousands - therefore omitting the use of proper pagination

Types involved:
Types involved:
Telemetry data is grouped into
attributes
and
timeseries data
Attributes are unique key-value pairs which are time-independant. Attributes can be set within a given scope
and for a given entity type
Use
to get attribute keys for an entity type
. This method does not support filtering by entity scope.
Use
to get
attribute keys
for an entity type
filtered
by entity scope
retrieves complete attributes: key and its current value.

code: myClient?.getAttributes(for: .device, entityId: tbDevice, keys: ["sampleAtt1String", "sampleAtt2Bool", "sampleAtt3Int", "sampleAtt4Double"]) { attributesArray in

retrieves complete attributes: key and its current value. This method requires to provide the desired attribute scope

code: myClient?.getAttributesByScope(for: .device, entityId: "entityId-as-UUID-string", keys: ["sampleAtt1String", "sampleAtt2Bool", "sampleAtt3Int", "sampleAtt4Double"], scope: .shared) { attributesArray in

Add new or modify existing attributes. Attributes can be defined as a
dictionary. The response handler
is called when the operation completes successfully. Attributes are set for a given entity
and scope

code: let sampleAttributes = ["sampleAtt1String":"Hello Server", "sampleAtt2Bool": true, "sampleAtt3Int": 4, "sampleAtt4Double": 3.1415926] as [String : Any]

inlineContent.text: Existing attributes can be deleted by providing its keys inside an array.
takes a completion handler which is called on success. Attributes are deleted for a given entity
and scope

Timeseries data work quite similar to attributes but are time-sensitive. It basically consists of a key-value pair but includes a timestamp. Available methods are quite similar to attributes methods. The timestamp is given as integer in milliseconds unix time (time since epoche 1970). In future versions, types containing
integer-timestamp-properties
might be extended to have another timestamp-property of the swift native type
Date
Request timeseries data keys for given entity.
requires to provide entity by its UUID string and calls a completion handler on success. The completion handler takes the retrieved key names as argument (of type
). Keys are retrieved for a given entity
Request latest timeseries data for given entity (
). Response contains last (youngest) timeseries data: a single key-value pair including timestamp.
has a parameter
. This tells the server to respond with all values as strings and not as native datatypes, such as int, bool, float. When a value contains a JSON string, it is highly recommended to set
because parsing JSON strings inside response values is currently not supported by this library.
Timeseries data is retrieved for a given entity

code: myClient?.getLatestTimeseries(for: .device, entityId: "entityId-as-UUID-string", keys: ["SampleIMEI", "SampleBattery"], getValuesAsStrings: false) { responseObject in
if let sampleimei = responseObject["SampleIMEI"], let samplebattery = responseObject["SampleBattery"] {
print("Expected key is missing in response!")

Timeseries data can be deleted for a specific timeframe, given the entity (
), identified based on its id, type and key names. To delete all timeseries data for a given entity and key, provide timeframe starting with 0 and ending with current datetime:
. On success, the completion handler is called.

code: myClient?.deleteEntityTimeseries(for: .device, entityId: "entityId-as-UUID-string", keys: ["SampleIMEI", "SampleBattery"], startTs: 0, endTs: dateTimeNow, deleteLatest: true) {

Simple client library for ThingsBoard server installations implementing the administration / user-space API (not device API) – written in Swift.
Represent a swift-native type for: ThingsBoard entity attribute
This library can be added to your Xcode or SPM project.
